acute_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Acute

acute_toxicity_dermal.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of >2000 mg/kg bw for rats (DFGOT vol. 23 (2007)), the substance was classified as "Not classified" in JIS Classification (correspond to Category 5 or "Not classified" in GHS classification).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.hazard_name: Acute toxicity Inhalation: Dusts and mists
acute_toxicity_inhalation_dust.rationale: Based on a LC50 value of >5 mg/L/4h (calculated from >3584 mgSb/m3 using molecular weight ratio) for rats (DFGOT vol. 23 (2007)), the substance was classified as "Not classified" in JIS Classification (correspond to Category 5 or "Not classified" in GHS classification).

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on a LD50 value of >2000 mg/kg bw [converted from >1434 mgSb/kg bw by molecular-weight ratio] for rats (DFGOT vol. 23 (2007)), the substance was classified into "Not classified" in JIS Classification (correspond to Category 5 or "Not classified" in GHS classification).

carcinogenicity.rationale: Based on the classification of "Group 3" in IARC (IARC 47 (1989)), the substance was classified as "Not classified". There is information that lung tumours occurred in females only in a rat test following repeated inhalation to antimony ore containing principally antimony trisulfide (IARC 47 (1989)). As relevant information, antimony and its inorganic compounds (inhalable fraction) are classified into "Carcinogenicity Category 2" in MAK/BAT (DFGOT 23, 2007).

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.hazard_name: Hazardous to the aquatic environment Long-term

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available.

explosives.rationale: There are no chemical groups associated with explosive properties present in the molecules.

flammable_gases.hazard_name: Flammable gases including chemically unstable gases

germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: No data available. As relevant information, antimony and its inorganic compounds (inhalable fraction) are classified as "Germ cell mutagen group 3B" in MAK/BAT (DFGOT 23, 2007).

oxidizing_solids.rationale: Inorganic compounds containing no oxygen and halogen atoms

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: The substance can be judged not to spontaneously ignite on contact with room temperature air from information such as "The substance burns on heating and its fine powder is oxidized gradually at room temperature." (Incompatible Hazard Handbook of Chemicals (Tokyo Fire Department, 1997)) or "The substance is incombustible." (IUCLID (2000)).

self_reactive_substances.rationale: There are no chemical groups present in the molecule associated with explosive or self-reactive properties.

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on results that slight corneal opacity was observed and was completely reversible within day 14 in a rabbit test following application of 100 mg (OECD TG405) (DFGOT vol. 23 (2007)), the substance was classified into Category 2A.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: No data available. As relevant information, there is a report that antimony fumes may cause skin irritation (Risk assessment report of antimony and antimony compounds (Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare) (2009)).

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases
substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.rationale: Classified into Not classified since data on water solubility at around room temperature (ATSDR (1992), HSDB (2009)) are available.

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (cardiovascular system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Rats exposed to 3.1 mg/m3 by inhalation for six weeks developed electrocardiographic changes, notably with flattened T-waves. At autopsy, the heart was found to be dilated, with signs of degenerative changes. Focal haemorrhage and congestion in the lungs were considered to be secondary to heart failure (IARC 47 (1989)). A second report indicates that there had been six deaths suspected due to cardiac disorder in a group of 125 workers exposed for 8 months to 2 years, but there had been no cardiac death or unusual increase in incidence of cardiovascular diseases after use of antimony trisulfide was discontinued (Initial Risk Assessment Report (NITE, CERI, NEDO) (2008)). Based on these findings, the substance was classified into Category 1 (cardiovascular system). As relevant information, there is a report indicating an increase in the incidence of deaths from non-neoplastic respiratory disease after exposure of antimony (Risk assessment report of antimony and antimony compounds (Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare) (2009)).

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
